description: From Middle English hayle, haile, hail, from Old English hæġl, hæġel, from Proto-Germanic *haglaz (compare West Frisian heil, Low German Hagel, Dutch hagel, German Hagel, Danish hagl,  Norwegian hagl)). Either from Proto-Indo-European *kagʰlos (“pebble”), or from *ḱoḱló-, a reduplication of *ḱel- (“cold”) (compare Old Norse héla (“frost”)).

Root-cognates outside of Germanic include Welsh caill (“testicle”), Breton kell (“testicle”), Lithuanian šešėlis (“shade, shadow”), Ancient Greek κάχληξ (kákhlēx, “pebble”), Albanian çakëll (“pebble”), Sanskrit शिशिर (śíśira, “cool, cold”).

entries.meaning: (meteorology, uncountable) Balls or pieces of ice falling as precipitation, often in connection with a thunderstorm.
(meteorology, countable) An occurrence of this type of precipitation; a hailstorm.
(countable, by extension) A rapid, intense barrage by a large number of projectiles or other objects.

verbs.description: hail (third-person singular simple present hails, present participle hailing, simple past and past participle hailed)

entries.meaning: (impersonal) Of hail, to fall from the sky.
examples: They say it's going to hail tomorrow.
The cloud would hail down furiously within a few minutes.

entries.meaning: To pour down in rapid succession.

description: From Middle English heil (“healthy, sound”), from Old Norse heill, from Proto-Germanic *hailaz (“whole, entire, healthy”). The verb is from Middle English heilen, itself from the adjective. Doublet of whole, hale, and heil.

verbs.description: hail (third-person singular simple present hails, present participle hailing, simple past and past participle hailed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To greet; give salutation to; salute.
(transitive) To name; to designate; to call.
examples: He was hailed as a hero.

definitionGroups.group: (transitive) To call out loudly in order to gain the attention of.

entries.meaning: (transitive, by extension, UK, Australia) To indicate, from a designated stop or otherwise, to the driver of a public transport vehicle that one wishes to board and travel on the vehicle, usually using hand signals such as waving.
examples: In Melbourne, you would usually have to hail a tram when you are travelling late at night and there are no other passengers waiting at your stop.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To signal in order to initiate communication with.
